data.title: Research Seminars
data.text:
Thursday, November 14

3:00 pm – 4:15 pm

316 Lake Hall

Claudia Goldin is the Henry Lee Professor of Economics at Harvard University. In October 2023, Professor Goldin was awarded the Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Sciences “for having advanced our understanding of women’s labor market outcomes”. The third woman to win the award, she was the first woman to win the award solo.

Assistant Professor of Economics

Jianfei Cao studies applied and theoretical econometrics. His research has chiefly been in the areas of machine learning methods in economic applications, causal inference in comparative case studies, and weak identification. His most recent research…

Assistant Professor of Economics

Shariq Mohammed is an Assistant Professor of Economics at Northeastern University. His research interests lie at the intersection of labor economics, economic history, and development economics. His current research focuses on two central and related…

Anna Aizer Maurice R. Greenberg Professor of Economics Brown University

Anna Aizer presented “What Happens when the Public Invests in Training Women? Community Colleges, Public Funding, and the Training of Nurses in the US.” Anna Aizer is a labor & health economist with interests in the area of child health and well-being. She is also co-director of the NBER’s program on Children.

Nicolás de Roux, Associate Professor, Universidad de los Andes, Colombia

Nicolás de Roux is an is an applied microeconomist doing research in development economics. He presented: Temperature Shocks and Land Fragmentation: Evidence from Transaction and Property Registry Data.

Marta Boczoń, Assistant Professor, Copenhagen Business School

Professor Boczoń’s research interests are Applied Econometrics, Crime Economics and Statistical Methods and Methodology. She presented “Screen vs Scene: Impact of News and TV on Belief Formation.”

Ahmed Mushfiq Mobarak, Professor of Management and Economics at Yale University

Ahmed Mushfiq Mobarak is the Jerome Kasoff ’54 Professor of Management and Economics at Yale with concurrent appointments in the School of Management and in the Department of Economics. Professor Mobarak presented Daughters Left Behind: How Trade Liberalization Harms Girls in China when Government Restricts Migration.

Angelino Viceisza, Professor of Economics, Spelman College

Dr. Angelino Viceisza , Professor of Economics at Spelman College, presented: “Fintech Visual Attention, and Financial Inclusion: A Field Experiment on Migrant Remittances.” Dr. Viceisza’s primary expertise is in behavioral and experimental economics, with applications in development, household finance, and entrepreneurship.

Romaine A. Campbell

Romaine A. Campbell’s main areas of interest are labor economics, the economics of crime, and the economics of education. He presented What Does Federal Oversight Do to Policing and Public Safety? Evidence from Seattle.

Kei-Mu Yi, M.D. Anderson Professor of Economics, University of Houston

Professor Kei-Mu Yi presented Deindustrialization and Industry Polarization. His current research interests are on the interrelationships between trade, growth, global value chains, and structural change.

Thomas Barnay, Visiting Professor in Economics at Northeastern University, will present “The impact of COVID-19 policies on self-reported depression among adults aged 50 and over in the US & Europe”

Professor Thomas Barnay is a Health Economist. His research deals with working conditions, and employment, C-19 and mental health issues, with a public health policy dimension.

Raisa Sherif, Post-doc, Max Planck Institute for Tax Law and Public Finance in Munich

Dr. Raisa Sherif presented “Are pro-environment behaviours substitutes or complements? Evidence from the field.” The goal of Dr. Sherif’s research is to better understand pro-environmental behaviours and policy interventions.

Laura Gee, Associate Professor of Economics at Tufts University, presented “Measuring Discrimination When Subjects Are Told They Are in an Experiment.”

Professor Laura Gee is a behavioral economist with a broad interest in how we can design institutions to influence individual decisions when individual decisions are intertwined with the actions of a group.
